[[File:Fort Worth Bank One Building damage edited.jpg|thumb|300px|Windows and outer walls of the Bank One Building in downtown [[Fort Worth, Texas]] were damaged by the [[2000 Fort Worth tornado]]. It is a commonly held belief that tornadoes cannot strike downtown areas, but Fort Worth is just one of many cities which have been struck by significant tornadoes.]]
'''Tornado myths''' are incorrect beliefs about [[tornado]]es, which can be attributed to many factors, including stories and news reports told by people unfamiliar with tornadoes, [[sensationalism]] by [[news media]], and the presentation of incorrect information in popular entertainment. Common myths cover various aspects of the tornado, and include ideas about tornado safety, the minimization of tornado damage, and false assumptions about the size, shape, power, and path of the tornado itself.
Some people incorrectly believe that opening windows ahead of a tornado will reduce the damage from the storm, but this is not true. Some people also believe that escaping in a vehicle is the safest method of avoiding a tornado, but this could increase the danger in some situations. Other myths are that tornadoes can skip houses, always travel in a predictable direction, always extend visibly from the ground to the cloud, and increase in intensity with increasing width. Finally, some people believe that tornadoes only occur in [[North America]], do not occur in winter, are attracted to [[trailer park]] homes, or that some areas are protected from tornadoes by rivers, mountains, valleys, tall buildings or other geographical or man-made features; the truth is that tornadoes can occur almost anywhere at any time if the conditions are right. Some geographic areas are simply more prone to these conditions than others.
Some tornado myths are remaining bits of folklore which are passed down by word of mouth. The idea that the southwest corner of a structure is the safest place in a tornado was first published in the 1800s and persisted until the 1990s despite being thoroughly debunked in the 1960s and 70s.<ref name="tornado project"/> One notable instance of mass media spreading a tornado myth was after the [[1999 Oklahoma tornado outbreak]], where [[TIME magazine]] ran a caption on a picture suggesting that highway overpasses were safer tornado shelters than houses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/oun/?n=safety-overpass|title=Highway Overpasses as Tornado Shelters|last=Miller|first=Daniel J.|year=1999|publisher=National Weather Service WFO [[Norman, Oklahoma]]|page=2|author2=Doswell, Charles A. III|author3=Brooks, Harold E.|author4=Stumpf, Gregory J.|author5=Rasmussen, Erik|accessdate=June 29, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.time.com/time/daily/special/photo/tornado/3.html|title=The Force of Nature|last=Carter|first=J. Pat|date=1999-05-04|publisher=TIME magazine|accessdate=June 30, 2009}}</ref> The spread of some myths can be attributed to popular tornado-themed movies such as ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]'' and ''[[Twister (1996 film)|Twister]]''.<ref name="Grazulis 7">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N6Tiz_7VmJoC&printsec=frontcover|title=The Tornado: Nature's Ultimate Windstorm|last=Grazulis|first=Thomas P|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|year=2001|isbn=0806132582|page=7|format=Google Books|authorlink=Thomas P. Grazulis|accessdate=2009-02-15}}</ref>
==Safety==
{{main|Tornado preparedness}}
===Safest location in a building=== [[Image:Tornado damage interior room.jpg|thumb|The central room on the lowest floor of a house is by far the safest area during a tornado. In multilevel apartment buildings, this will mean the ground floor units. Often the upper levels are built with lighter, weaker materials. This house near [[Jasper, Texas]] was destroyed by an [[Fujita scale|F2 tornado]], with only a few interior walls still standing.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.srh.noaa.gov/lch/?n=e111703|title= Tornadoes & Severe Weather November 17th & 18th, 2003|accessdate=2008-06-24|date=2008-03-06|publisher= [[National Weather Service]], [[Lake Charles, Louisiana]]}}</ref>]] In 1887, the first book on tornadoes was written by [[John Park Finley]], a pioneer in the field of tornado research. While it was a revolutionary book containing many breakthrough ideas, it contained a few ideas which have since been proven false.<ref name="tornado project">{{cite web|url= http://www.tornadoproject.com/safety/myths.htm|title= Myths and Misconceptions about Tornadoes|accessdate=2013-05-31|year= 1999|publisher= [[Tornado Project]]}}</ref><ref>[http://www.tornadofacts.net/tornado-myths.php Tornado Myths] - Tornado Fact vs. Fiction</ref> One of these was the idea that the northeast or east part of a structure was the least safe, and should be avoided when seeking shelter from a tornado.
This myth was derived from two misconceptions: First, that tornadoes always travel in a northeasterly direction, and second, that debris from a structure will be carried away in the direction of the tornado's propagation, leaving anyone taking shelter on the side of the structure facing the tornado's approach unharmed.<ref name="tornado project"/><ref name="mkx myths">{{cite web |author = MKX Webmaster |title = Severe Weather Awareness - Common Tornado Myths |url = http://www.crh.noaa.gov/mkx/?n=taw-part2-tornado_myths |publisher = National Weather Service |location = [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin]]/[[Sullivan, Wisconsin|Sullivan, WI]] |date = April 10, 2009 |accessdate = June 29, 2009}}</ref> The seriousness of these misconceptions began to be revealed in the 1960s and 1970s, when surveys of major tornado damage in residential areas showed that the section of a house in the direction of the tornado's approach is actually the {{em|least}} safe.<ref name="tornado project"/> Additionally, many tornadoes have traveled in directions other than northeasterly, including the [[Central Texas tornado outbreak|Jarrell Tornado]] (F5 on the [[Fujita scale]]), which moved south-southwesterly.<ref name="tornado project"/><ref name="overpass">{{cite web |first = Daniel J. |last = Miller |author2=Doswell, Charles A. III |author3=Brooks, Harold E. |author4=Stumpf, Gregory J. |author5=Rasmussen, Erik |title = Highway Overpasses as Tornado Shelters |url = http://www.srh.noaa.gov/oun/?n=safety-overpass |publisher = National Weather Service WFO [[Norman, Oklahoma]] |year = 1999 |accessdate = June 29, 2009}}</ref> Because determining a tornado's direction of approach can take time away from seeking shelter, official advice is to seek shelter in an interior room on the lowest floor of a building, under a staircase, [[I-beam]], or sturdy piece of furniture if possible.<ref name="mkx myths"/>
===Opening windows to reduce tornado damage=== One of the oldest pieces of tornado folklore is the idea that tornadoes do most of their damage due to the lower [[atmospheric pressure]] at the center of a tornado, which causes the house to explode outward. As the theory goes, opening windows helps to equalize the pressure.<ref name="BCEMA">{{cite web |title=Tornado Information for Schools |url=http://www.butlercountyohio.org/ema/pdf/tornado%20info%20for%20schools.pdf |publisher=[[Butler County, Ohio]] Emergency Management Agency |format=PDF |accessdate=June 29, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070509044255/http://www.butlercountyohio.org/ema/pdf/tornado%20info%20for%20schools.pdf |archivedate=May 9, 2007 |df= }} Cited link is not found. {{cite web |title=Wayback article |url=http://www.butlercountyohio.org/ema/pdf/tornado%20info%20for%20schools.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=May 9, 2007 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070509044255/http://www.butlercountyohio.org/ema/pdf/tornado%20info%20for%20schools.pdf |archivedate=May 9, 2007 }}</ref>
The source of this myth is from the appearance of some destroyed structures after violent tornadoes. When one wall receives the extreme pressure of tornado winds, it will likely collapse {{em|inward}}. This then leads to a considerable {{em|outward}} pressure on the three remaining walls, which fall outwards as the roof falls down, creating the impression of a house which has exploded. Indeed, damage surveys of "exploded" houses usually show at least one wall which has blown inward.<ref name="BCEMA"/> Additionally, if the roof is lifted before any walls fall, the walls can fall in any direction. If they fall outward, this structure can also appear to have exploded.<ref>{{cite web |first = Bob |last = Ryan |title = Answers archive: Tornado safety |url = https://www.usatoday.com/weather/resources/askjack/watorsaf.htm |publisher = [[USA Today]] |date = December 15, 2005 |accessdate = June 29, 2009}}</ref>
In even the most violent tornadoes, there is only a pressure drop of about 10%, which is about {{convert|1.4|psi|kPa}}.<ref name="Manchester">{{cite conference |first=Julian J. |last=Lee |author2=T.P. Samaras |author3=C.R. Young |title=Pressure Measurements at the ground in an F-4 tornado |booktitle=Preprints of the 22nd Conference on Severe Local Storms |publisher=[[American Meteorological Society]] |date=October 2004 |location=Hyannis, Massachusetts |url=http://ams.confex.com/ams/11aram22sls/techprogram/paper_81700.htm }}</ref> Not only can this difference be equalized in most structures in approximately three seconds, but if a significant pressure differential manages to form, the windows will break first, equalizing the pressure.<ref name="tornado project"/> Additionally, as the windows are the most fragile parts of a house, in a significant tornado flying debris will likely break enough windows to equalize any pressure difference fairly quickly. Regardless of any pressure drop, the direct effects of a tornado's winds are enough to cause damage to a house in all but the weakest tornadoes.<ref name="tornado project"/><ref name="mkx myths"/>
Current advice is that opening windows in advance of a tornado wastes time that could be spent seeking shelter. Also, being near windows is very dangerous during a severe weather event, possibly exposing people to flying glass.<ref name="SPC FAQ"/>
===Using highway overpasses as shelter=== [[Image:Overpass comparison.PNG|thumb|The El Dorado Lake tornado overpass, above, had an unusual construction which provided a sheltered area for the camera crew. Most overpasses, like the Shields Boulevard Overpass at bottom, provide little or no shelter to tornado winds and flying debris.<ref name="overpass"/>]]
There are several documented cases of people surviving under highway overpasses, but scientists and meteorologists warn against using them for protection.<ref name="weathersafety.ohio.gov">{{Cite web|url=http://www.weathersafety.ohio.gov/TornadoSafety.aspx|title=Ohio.gov {{!}} OCSWA {{!}} Tornado Safety & the Dangers of Highway Overpasses|website=www.weathersafety.ohio.gov|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref name="overpass"/> From scientific lessons learned, meteorologists insist that overpasses are insufficient shelter from tornado winds and debris, and may be {{em|the worst place}} to be during a violent tornado.<ref name="overpass" /><ref name="weathersafety.ohio.gov"/> The embankment under an overpass is higher than the surrounding terrain, and the wind speed increases with height. Additionally, the overpass design may create a "[[wind tunnel|wind-tunnel]]" effect under the span, further increasing the wind speed. Many overpasses are completely exposed underneath and most lack hanging girders or a crawlspace-like area to provide sufficient protection from debris, which can travel at high speeds even in weak tornadoes. ({{em|If}} a highway underpass is close at hand, and {{em|if}} it has such deep crawlspaces behind sheltering girders, and {{em|if}} no better shelter is available in the face of imminent danger from a tornado, then this could be the best and most survivable option. Otherwise, an underpass is no shelter at all.) People stopping underneath overpasses block the flow of traffic, putting others in danger.<ref name="overpass" /><ref>{{cite web |title = Severe Weather Safety Guide |url = http://www.crh.noaa.gov/images/pah/pdf/tornadosafety.pdf |publisher = National Weather Service [[Paducah, Kentucky]] |format = PDF |date=2007-12-12|accessdate = June 29, 2009}}</ref>
===Escaping a tornado in a vehicle=== [[Image:School damage Caledonia.jpg|thumb|right|A [[Tornadoes of 2008#January 7–10|2008 tornado]] lifted this school bus and flipped it on top of a damaged elementary school in [[Caledonia, Mississippi]].]] Often people try to avoid or outrun a tornado in a vehicle. Although cars can travel faster than the average tornado, the directive from the National Weather Service is for house-dwellers in the path of a tornado to take shelter at home rather than risk an escape by vehicle.<ref name="tornado safety in vehicle">{{cite web|first=Van L.|last=DeWald|title=Tornado Safety in Your Vehicle|url=http://www.crh.noaa.gov/lmk/spotter_reference/spotter_slideshow/slide71.php|work=[http://www.crh.noaa.gov/lmk/spotter_reference/spotter_slideshow/slide1.php National Weather Service Storm Spotting and Weather Safety]|publisher=National Weather Service [[Louisville, Kentucky]]|page=71|date=February 26, 1999|accessdate=June 29, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090417023728/http://www.crh.noaa.gov/lmk/spotter_reference/spotter_slideshow/slide71.php|archivedate=April 17, 2009|df=}}</ref> This is a result of several factors and statistics. An interior room inside a well-built frame house (especially one with a [[basement]]) provides a reasonable degree of protection from all but the most violent tornadoes. Underground or above-ground [[tornado shelter]]s, as well as extremely strong structures such as [[bank vault]]s, offer almost complete protection. Cars, on the other hand, can be heavily damaged by even weak tornadoes, and in violent tornadoes they can be thrown large distances, even into buildings. High-profile vehicles such as [[bus]]es and [[tractor trailer]]s are even more vulnerable to high winds.<ref name="Wichita Falls"/><ref name="tornado project cars">{{cite web|url=http://www.tornadoproject.com/safety/cars.htm|title=Tornado Safety in Cars|date=1999|publisher=[[The Tornado Project]]|accessdate=2009-06-11}}</ref>
There are many reasons to avoid cars when a tornado is imminent. Severe thunderstorms which produce tornadoes can produce flooding rains, hail, and strong winds far from the tornado-producing area, all of which can make driving difficult or even impossible. Any of these situations can leave drivers stranded in the path of the tornado far from substantial shelter.<ref name="tornado project cars"/> When coupled with driver panic, they may also result in dangerous but preventable accidents.<ref name="tornado project cars"/> This situation would be magnified greatly if all the residents of a warned area left in their vehicles, which would cause traffic jams and accidents as the tornado approached.<ref name="tornado project cars"/> Numerous victims of the deadly [[Red River Valley Tornado Outbreak|Wichita Falls, Texas tornado]] on April 10, 1979 died in their vehicles in such a situation.<ref name="Wichita Falls">{{cite web|url= http://www.srh.noaa.gov/oun/?n=events-19790410-burgess|title= The April 10, 1979 Severe Weather Outbreak|accessdate= 2008-06-22|last= Burgess|first= Don |date= 2006-06-13|publisher= [[National Weather Service]] [[Norman, Oklahoma]]}}</ref>
If a person spots a nearby tornado while driving, the official National Weather Service directive has been for the individual to abandon the car and seek shelter in a ditch or culvert, or substantial shelter if nearby.<ref name="tornado safety in vehicle"/> Far-away, highly visible tornadoes, however, can be successfully fled from at right angles (90-degrees) from its direction of apparent movement.<ref name="SPC FAQ"/> Despite dangers inherent with operating a vehicle during a tornado, given sufficient advance warning, mobile home residents have been instructed by the National Weather Service to drive to the nearest secure shelter during a warning.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crh.noaa.gov/lmk/spotter_reference/spotter_slideshow/slide69.php|title=Tornado Safety in Your Mobile Home|last=DeWald|first=Van L.|date=February 26, 1999|publisher=National Weather Service, Louisville, Kentucky|accessdate=2009-06-11}}</ref>
==Tornado behavior==
===Tornadoes skipping houses=== Several different phenomena have lent credence to the idea that tornadoes "skip" houses, like a person jumping over hurdles.<ref name="SPC FAQ">{{cite web |first= Roger |last= Edwards |authorlink= Roger Edwards (meteorologist) |title= The Online Tornado FAQ |url= http://www.spc.ncep.noaa.gov/faq/tornado |publisher= [[Storm Prediction Center]] |date= January 29, 2009 |accessdate= June 29, 2009}}</ref> Tornadoes vary in intensity along their path, sometimes drastically over a short period and distance. If a tornado was causing damage, then weakened to the point where it could cause no damage, followed by a re-intensification, it would appear as if it skipped a section. Occasionally with violent tornadoes, a smaller [[multiple vortex tornado|subvortex]] within a tornado will completely destroy a structure next to another building which appears almost unscathed and thus apparently skipped over.<ref name="SPC FAQ"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/oun/?n=faq-tornadoes|title=What are some common tornado myths?|date=2008-10-20|publisher=National Weather Service, Norman, Oklahoma|accessdate=2009-06-11}}</ref>
It is true that a house that is between two destroyed homes can be undamaged, but this is not the result of a tornado skipping, as some previously thought. After the [[1974 Super Outbreak]], Dr. [[Ted Fujita]] studied many films of tornadoes from that day. Included in his review was damage and tornado film footage of F4 and F5 tornadoes. Fujita concluded that multiple vortices, highly volatile tornadic satellites transiting within a parent tornado at high speeds, are responsible for making tornadoes appear to skip houses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/publications/mccarthy/tor30yrs.pdf|title=Tornado Trends Over the Past Thirty Years|last=McCarthy|first=Daniel|author2=Schaefer, Joseph |publisher=Storm Prediction Center|date=2003-11-10|accessdate=2009-06-11}}</ref> The phenomenon of [[satellite tornado]]es, where a smaller tornado orbits a larger companion tornado, can also lead to gaps in damage between the two tornadoes.
Weaker tornadoes, and at times even stronger tornadoes, can occasionally lift, meaning their circulation ceases to affect the ground. The result is an erratic and discontinuous linear damage path, leading to the term [[skipping tornado]]. These discontinuities tend to occur over areas larger than the small neighborhoods where the house-skipping effect is observed, except possibly at the time of the birth and organization of the tornado.<ref name="norman">{{cite web |title= Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) |url= http://www.srh.noaa.gov/oun/office/faq.php?c=Tornadoes&i=Myths |publisher= National Weather Service Norman, Oklahoma |date= October 20, 2008 |accessdate= June 29, 2009 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080407184957/http://www.srh.noaa.gov/oun/office/faq.php?c=Tornadoes&i=Myths |archivedate= April 7, 2008}}</ref> This situation is not commonly observed and the term is now rarely applied. Typically, when one tornado weakens and another forms, the process of successive parent [[mesocyclone]]s forming and decaying is known as [[Tornadogenesis|cyclic tornadogenesis]], thus leading to a series of tornadoes spawned by the same supercell. This series of tornadoes is known as a [[tornado family]].
===Association of size with intensity=== [[Image:F5 tornado Elie Manitoba 2007.jpg|thumb|The [[Elie, Manitoba Tornado]] of June 22, 2007 appeared small and narrow throughout its lifespan, yet was the first tornado in [[History of Canada|Canadian history]] to cause [[Fujita scale|F5]] damage.]] Some people have been led to assume that small, skinny tornadoes are always weaker than large, wedge-shaped tornadoes.<ref name="mkx myths"/> There is an observed trend of wider tornadoes causing worse damage. It is unknown whether this is due to an actual tendency of tornado dynamics or an ability for the tornado to affect a larger area.<ref name="SPC FAQ"/> However, this is not a reliable indicator of an individual tornado's intensity. Some small, rope-like tornadoes, traditionally thought of as weak, have been among the strongest in history.<ref name="SPC FAQ"/> Since 1950, more than 100 violent tornadoes ([[Fujita scale|F4]]/[[Enhanced Fujita Scale|EF4]] or higher) had a maximum width of {{convert|300|ft|m}}.<ref name="severe plot">Data from the [[Storm Prediction Center]] archives, which are accessible through [http://www.spc.noaa.gov/software/svrplot2/ SeverePlot], free software created and maintained by [[John Hart (meteorologist)|John Hart]], lead forecaster for the SPC.</ref> Also, tornadoes typically change shape during the course of their lifespan, further complicating any attempt to classify how dangerous a tornado is as it is occurring.<ref name="Advanced Spotter Guide">{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.gov/os/brochures/adv_spotters.pdf |title=Advanced Spotters' Field Guide |accessdate=2006-09-20 |author=Doswell, Moller, Anderson |year=2005 |format=PDF |publisher=[[United States Department of Commerce]] |display-authors=etal |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060823090940/http://www.weather.gov/os/brochures/adv_spotters.pdf |archivedate=2006-08-23 |df= }}</ref>
===Appearing to reach the ground=== It is commonly and mistakenly thought that if the [[condensation funnel]] of a tornado does not reach the ground, then the tornado cannot cause substantial damage. This is another deadly myth. A tornado appears to be on the ground only when its condensation funnel descends to the surface, but this is misleading. The circular, violent surface winds, not the condensation funnel, are what both define the tornado and cause the tornado's damage. Spotters should keep sight of swirling debris directly under any visible funnel or rotating wall cloud, even if such structures appear to not descend entirely to the ground.<ref name="Advanced Spotter Guide"/><ref name="WEMO">{{cite web|url=http://emergencymanagement.wi.gov/docview.asp?docid=16477&locid=18 |title=What you need to know about TORNADOES |publisher=[[Wisconsin]] [[Emergency Management Office]] |accessdate=2009-06-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090430050420/http://emergencymanagement.wi.gov/docview.asp?docid=16477&locid=18 |archivedate=April 30, 2009 }}</ref> Additionally, tornadoes can be wrapped in [[rain]] and thus may not be visible at all.<ref name="WEMO"/>
===Direction of travel=== It has been thought in the past that tornadoes moved almost exclusively in a northeasterly direction.<ref name="mkx myths"/> This is false, and a potentially deadly myth which can lead to a false sense of security, especially for unaware spotters or chasers. Although the majority of tornadoes move northeast, this is normally due to the motion of the storm, and tornadoes can arrive from any direction. The expectation of northeasterly travel may be accurate in many cases, but is no more than a statistical observation about tornadoes in general that any particular tornado may defy at any time. A deadly F5 tornado that hit the city of [[Jarrell, Texas]] in 1997 moved to the southwest - directly opposite of commonly expected storm motion. Additionally, tornadoes can shift without notice due to storm motion changes or effects on the tornado itself from factors such as its [[rear flank downdraft]].<ref name="SPC FAQ"/> This change of direction proved deadly in the [[2013 El Reno tornado]] in which a 2.6 mile wide tornado shifted from an east direction to a northeast direction killing at least 4 storm chasers.<ref name="SRH-NOAA May 31, 2013 Event Summary">{{cite web|last1=OUN Webmaster|title=The May 31, 2013 El Reno, OK Tornado|url=http://www.srh.noaa.gov/oun/?n=events-20130531-elreno|website=NWS WFO - Norman, OK|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=16 June 2015|ref=OUN Event Summary}}</ref>
==Geographical and temporal influences==
===Geographical scope=== [[File:Globdisttornado.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Areas worldwide where tornadoes are most likely, indicated by orange shading]] It is often thought that tornadoes only occur in [[North America]].<ref name="Global">{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/weather/resources/askjack/2004-05-19-global-tornadoes_x.htm|title=Answers: Do tornadoes occur outside the USA|last=Williams|first=Jack|date=2004-05-28|publisher=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=2009-06-11}}</ref> The majority of tornadoes do occur in the United States; however, tornadoes have been observed on every continent except [[Antarctica]].<ref name="Science News 1">{{cite web| url = http://www.sciencenews.org/articles/20020511/bob9.asp| title = Tornado Alley, USA| accessdate = 2006-09-20| last = Perkins| first = Sid| date = 2002-05-11| work = [[Science News]]| pages = 296–298 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060825011156/http://www.sciencenews.org/articles/20020511/bob9.asp |archivedate = August 25, 2006}}</ref>
Besides North America, [[Argentina]], [[Europe]], [[Australia]], the [[United Kingdom]], [[western Russia]], [[Bangladesh]] and the [[Philippines]] also experience tornadoes on a regular basis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/oa/climate/severeweather/tornadoes.html|title=U.S. Tornado Climatology|date=2008-04-10|publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]|accessdate=2009-06-11}}</ref> {{see also|Tornado climatology#Geography}}
===Near rivers, valleys, mountains, or other terrain features=== There are many misconceptions involving the effect of terrain features—bodies of water, mountains, valleys, and others—on tornado formation and behavior. While most modes of [[tornadogenesis]] are poorly understood,<ref name="Advanced Spotter Guide"/><ref>{{cite journal| last = Biggerstaff| first = Michael I.|author2=Wicker, Louis J. |author3=Guynes, Jerry |author4=Ziegler, Conrad |author5=Straka, Jerry M. |author6=Rasmussen, Erik N. |author7=Doggett, Arthur IV |author8=Carey, Larry D. |author9=Schroeder, John L. |author10= Weiss, Chris |date=September 2005| title = The Shared Mobile Atmospheric Research and Teaching Radar| journal = [[Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society]]| volume = 86| issue = 9| pages = 1263–1274| publisher = [[American Meteorological Society]]| doi = 10.1175/BAMS-86-9-1263| url = http://www.nssl.noaa.gov/projects/smartradars/pubs/SR-BAMS.pdf| format = PDF| accessdate = June 29, 2009|bibcode = 2005BAMS...86.1263B }}</ref> no terrain feature can prevent the occurrence of a tornado.<ref name="mkx myths"/>
Small bodies of water such as lakes and rivers are insignificant obstacles to tornadoes. Violent tornadoes have formed over rivers and lakes—including the [[1878 Wallingford tornado]] and the [[1899 New Richmond tornado]]—as well as crossing over them after forming elsewhere. More than a dozen tornadoes are reported to have crossed the [[Mississippi River]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Grazulis |first=Thomas P.|authorlink=Thomas P. Grazulis|title=The Tornado: Nature's Ultimate Windstorm|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N6Tiz_7VmJoC&printsec=frontcover|format=Google Books|accessdate=2009-02-15|year=2001|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=0806132582|chapter=Tornado Myths|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=N6Tiz_7VmJoC&printsec=frontcover#PPA146,M1|page=148}}</ref> Strong tornadoes have also been known to cross the [[Detroit River]] and St. Claire River separating southeast [[Michigan]] and southwest [[Ontario]].{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} Regarding mountains, tornadoes have been observed on terrain as high as {{convert|12000|ft|m}} above [[sea level]], and have been known to pass up a {{convert|3000|ft|m|adj=on}} ridge unaffected.<ref name="tornado project"/><ref>{{cite web |first= John |last= Monteverdi |author2=Edwards, Roger |author3=Stumpf, Greg |author4=Gudgel, Daniel |title= Tornado, Rockwell Pass Sequoia National Park, July 7, 2004 |url= http://tornado.sfsu.edu/RockwellPassTornado/index.html |date= September 13, 2006 |accessdate= June 29, 2009}}</ref>
These myths have been debunked. The devastating [[Tri-State Tornado]] crossed two major rivers along a record {{convert|219|mi|km|adj=on}} or longer path.<ref name="norman"/> In 1944, a violent tornado cut a continuous path at least {{convert|60|mi|km}} through heavily forested and mountainous territory in [[West Virginia]], killing at least 100 people.<ref>{{cite book | last = Grazulis | first = Thomas P | title = Significant Tornadoes 1680–1991 |date=July 1993 | publisher = The Tornado Project of Environmental Films | location = St. Johnsbury, VT | isbn = 1-879362-03-1 | page=915}}</ref> A hill known as Burnett's Mound on the southwest end of [[Topeka, Kansas]] was purported to protect the city from tornadoes, according to an old legend. However, in 1966, an [[1966 Topeka tornado|F5 tornado]] passed directly over the hill through downtown, killing 18 people and causing $100 million (1966 [[United States dollar|USD]]) in damage.<ref>{{cite book|last=Grazulis |first=Thomas P|authorlink=Thomas P. Grazulis|title=The Tornado: Nature's Ultimate Windstorm|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N6Tiz_7VmJoC&printsec=frontcover|format=Google Books|accessdate=2009-02-15|year=2001|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=0806132582|chapter=Tornado Myths|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=N6Tiz_7VmJoC&printsec=frontcover#PPA146,M1|pages=146–147}}</ref> Downtown [[Memphis, Tennessee]] was believed by residents to be protected from tornadoes and other severe weather by the [[Chickasaw Bluff]] along the [[Mississippi River]]. During the [[1974 Super Outbreak]], violent tornadoes crossed dozens of rivers, including the [[Ohio River|Ohio]], [[Detroit River]] as well as crossing over mountains and ridges hundreds of feet high.<ref>{{cite book | last = Grazulis | first = Thomas P | title = Significant Tornadoes 1680–1991 |date=July 1993 | publisher = The Tornado Project of Environmental Films | location = St. Johnsbury, VT | isbn = 1-879362-03-1 | pages=1153–1163}}</ref> Another example of tornadoes hitting mountainous regions of the United States is the [[2011 Super Outbreak]], which hit mountainous parts of [[East Tennessee]], Northeast Alabama, Southwest Virginia and North Georgia, killing many people, including an entire family of 4 in [[Ringgold, Georgia]].<ref name="Ringgold">[http://www.11alive.com/rss/article/188727/3/LIVE-VIDEO-At-least-11-killed-in-GA-deadly-storms Ringgold residents return to 'utter devastation' from tornadoes] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130101183902/http://www.11alive.com/rss/article/188727/3/LIVE-VIDEO-At-least-11-killed-in-GA-deadly-storms |date=2013-01-01 }}, [[WXIA-TV]], April 29, 2011. Retrieved April 30, 2011.</ref>
===Attraction to mobile homes and/or trailer parks=== [[File:Spencer County, Kentucky tornado damage 2008-02-06.JPG|thumb|This mobile home was destroyed by a relatively weak [[Enhanced Fujita Scale|EF0 tornado]].]] The idea that [[manufactured housing]] units, or [[mobile home]]s, attract tornadoes has been around for decades. This may appear to be true at first from looking at tornado fatality statistics: from 2000 to 2008, 539 people were killed by tornadoes in the US, with more than half (282) of those deaths in mobile homes.<ref name="SPC fatal">{{cite web |title = Annual U.S. Killer Tornado Statistics |url = http://www.spc.noaa.gov/climo/torn/fataltorn.html |publisher = Storm Prediction Center |date = June 17, 2009 |accessdate = June 29, 2009}}</ref> Only around 6.8% of homes in the US are "manufactured/mobile homes".<ref>{{cite web |title = Table 1A-2. Height and Condition of Building—All Housing Units |url = https://www.census.gov/hhes/www/housing/ahs/ahs07/tab1a-2.pdf |publisher = [[United States Census Bureau]] |format = PDF |date = 2007 |accessdate = June 29, 2009}}</ref>
However, it is highly unlikely that single-story structures such as mobile homes can have a substantial effect on tornado development or evolution. More people are killed in [[trailer park]]s because mobile homes are less able to withstand high winds than permanent structures. Winds which can demolish or roll a mobile home may only cause roof damage to a typical one- or two-family permanent residence.<ref>{{cite web|title=A Recommendation for an Enhanced Fujita Scale (EF-Scale) |url=http://www.wind.ttu.edu/EFScale.pdf |publisher=Wind Science and Engineering Center, [[Texas Tech University]] |format=PDF |date=2006-10-10 |accessdate=June 29, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090507002300/http://www.wind.ttu.edu/EFScale.pdf |archivedate=May 7, 2009 }}</ref> Another likely contributing factor to the continued propagation of this myth is [[confirmation bias]]: whenever a new instance of a tornado hitting a mobile home park occurs, media outlets report on it more extensively, ignoring damage to the surrounding area which may not have produced as many casualties.<ref>{{cite book|last=Grazulis |first=Thomas P|authorlink=Thomas P. Grazulis|title=The Tornado: Nature's Ultimate Windstorm|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N6Tiz_7VmJoC&printsec=frontcover|format=Google Books|accessdate=2009-02-15|year=2001|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=0806132582|chapter=Tornado Myths|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=N6Tiz_7VmJoC&printsec=frontcover#PPA146,M1|page=152}}</ref>
===Downtown areas=== {{See also|List of tornadoes striking downtown areas of large cities}} [[Image:1999 Salt Lake City tornado.jpg|thumb|right|Tornadoes are extremely rare in [[Utah]], but downtown [[Salt Lake City]] was struck by [[Salt Lake City Tornado|this F2 tornado]] in 1999, which killed one person.]] Some people believe that, for various reasons, large cities cannot be struck by tornadoes. More than 100 tornadoes have been reported to strike downtown areas of large cities. Many cities have been struck twice or more, and a few—including [[Lubbock, Texas]]; [[St. Louis, Missouri]]; [[Topeka, Kansas]]; and [[London]], [[England]]—have been struck by violent tornadoes ([[Fujita scale|F4]] or stronger).<ref name="severe plot"/><ref name="TORRO">{{cite web |title = British & European Tornado Extremes |url = http://www.torro.org.uk/site/whirlwind_info.php |publisher = [[TORRO]] |year = 2009 |accessdate = June 29, 2009}}</ref>
Tornadoes may seem rare in downtown areas because downtown areas cover such a small geographical area. Considering the size of a [[central business district]] is very small compared to the city limits, tornadoes will strike outside of the downtown area more often.<ref name="tornado project"/>
The misconception, like most, has a small basis in truth. Research has been done in a few metropolitan areas suggesting that the [[urban heat island]] effect may discourage the formation of weak tornadoes in city centers, due to turbulent warm air disrupting their formation. This does not apply to significant tornadoes, however, and it is possible that the presence of tall buildings may actually {{em|intensify}} storms which move into downtown areas.<ref name="tornado project"/>
===During winter=== {{See also|Tornado climatology|List of tornadoes by calendar day}} Because they generally require warm weather to form, tornadoes are uncommon in winter in the mid-latitudes.<ref>{{cite web |first = Deborah |last = Zabarenko |title = Deadly winter tornadoes not rare: NOAA |url = https://www.reuters.com/article/environmentNews/idUSN0630245820080207 |publisher = [[Reuters]] |date = February 7, 2008 |accessdate = June 29, 2009}}</ref> However, they can form, and tornadoes have even been known to travel over snow-covered surfaces.<ref name="Handy Weather Answer Book">{{cite book | last = Lyons | first = Walter A | title = The Handy Weather Answer Book | edition = 2nd | year = 1997 | publisher = Visible Ink press | location = [[Detroit, Michigan]] | isbn = 0-7876-1034-8 | pages = gs. 175–200 | chapter = Tornadoes }}</ref> Deadly tornadoes are no exception: from 2000 to 2008, 135 of the 539 US tornado deaths occurred during [[meteorological winter]] (December through February).<ref name="SPC fatal"/> Tornadoes in winter may be more dangerous, since they tend to move faster than tornadoes at other times of the year.<ref>{{cite web |first = Robert Roy |last = Britt |title = Tornadoes in Winter? |url = http://www.livescience.com/environment/090211-tornadoes-february.html |publisher = [[LiveScience]] |date = 2009-02-11 |accessdate = July 1, 2009}}</ref>
== See also == * [[List of common misconceptions]] * [[List of F5 and EF5 tornadoes]] * [[List of tornadoes and tornado outbreaks]] * [[List of tornadoes striking downtown areas]] * [[Tornado records]] * [[Tornado#Size and shape|Shape of tornadoes]] * [[Tornado#Size and shape|Size of tornadoes]] * [[Tornadoes of {{CURRENTYEAR}}]] * [[List of tornadoes by calendar day]]
== References == {{Reflist}} * {{cite journal |last = Klockow |first = Kimberly E. |authorlink = |author2=R. A. Peppler |author3=R. A. McPherson |title = Tornado Folk Science in Alabama and Mississippi in the 27 April 2011 Tornado Outbreak |journal = GeoJournal |volume = |issue = |pages = |date = 2014 |url = |doi = 10.1007/s10708-013-9518-6 }}
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071227145208/http://lwf.ncdc.noaa.gov/oa/climate/severeweather/tornadosafety.html#myths Tornado Myths and Facts] ''[[National Climatic Data Center]]'' * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XCjxNJQmWnM Video comparing houses with open and closed doors in high winds] - though [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RD8ZZjeQmC4 construction is also different]
{{good article}}

revision.text:
The Wu number (<math>Wu</math>) is a nondimensional quantity in [[fluid mechanics]] describing the effects of rotating axisymmetric bodies on wall-bounded sheer flows. The parameter is named after the Chinese scientist Yongxiang Wu during his work on [[boundary layer]] instabilities.
== Definition == The Wu number is defined as.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Max|first=Nüßle|date=2017|title=Experimentelle Untersuchung zu Instabiliätsmechanismen hinter einer rotierenden Einzelrauigkeit in laminaren Grenzschichten|url=|journal=Bachelor thesis|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
<math>Wu = \frac{\omega D}{2u_k}</math>,
where <math>\omega</math> is the circular frequency, <math>D</math> the diameter of the axisymmetric body (like for instance a cylinder) and <math>u_k</math> the local flow velocity at the top of the body. It is therefore the ratio of the velocities of the body edge and the surrounding flow.
== Applications == Rotating bodies on boundary layers are a means of active flow control on [[wings]], [[Empennage|empanage]] or [[Stabilizer (aeronautics)|stabilizers]] on [[Airplane|airplanes]]. For large Wu numbers (<math>Wu\gg1</math>), the instability mechanisms are governed by the rotation of the body. For small Wu numbers (<math>Wu\ll1</math>) the stability-related effects of the body itself may outweigh its rotatory effects<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wu|first=Yongxiang|date=2018|others=Proposed Contribution|title=Stability of Rotating Cylindrical Roughness Element in Boundary Layer|url=|journal=New Results in Numerical and Experimental Fluid Mechanics. Contribution to the STAB Symposium 2018 in Dortmund, Germany.|volume=XII|pages=|via=}}</ref>
== See also ==
* [[Strouhal number]] * [[Reynolds number]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
